Story: I was standing in the small, fluorescent-lit office at the back of the grocery store, my son’s eyes red and downcast as the manager explained what had happened. My heart pounded with the weight of what I needed to do as a father—teach him right from wrong, show him that actions have consequences, and somehow guide him through this mistake with love and firmness. I was just about to speak when my phone buzzed urgently in my pocket. It was a message from Mark, my oldest friend: “Car broke down on the highway. It’s freezing. Please, can you come get me? No one else is picking up.” I stared at the screen, torn. Mark had always been there for me, and I knew he was counting on me now. But my son needed me, right here, right now, to be the father he deserved. The pressure of both roles pressed in on me, each demanding my presence, each impossible to ignore. My mind raced, caught between the desperate plea of my friend and the silent, trembling need of my child.
